repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Use them in preference to the existing compiler-specific
atomic types.

In both cases this requires the 2011 edition of the standard.

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4923

comment_data.body: For the master branch I've also now removed this `CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_NOGIL` flag, which was there to make https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4915 lower risk for 0.29.x
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -37,11 +69,12 @@ typedef struct {
     #ifdef __PYX_DEBUG_ATOMICS
         #warning "Using GNU atomics"
     #endif
-#elif CYTHON_ATOMICS && defined(_MSC_VER) && CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_NOGIL
+#elif CYTHON_ATOMICS && defined(_MSC_VER)

comment_data.body: This comparison seems to want to have an actual value on the RHS?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,8 +26,58 @@ typedef struct {
 #endif
 
 #define __pyx_atomic_int_type int
+#define __pyx_nonatomic_int_type int
+
+// for standard C/C++ atomics, get the headers first so we have ATOMIC_INT_LOCK_FREE
+// defined when we decide to use them
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \

comment_data.body:
I think this is correct, but may be a bit confusing (because VS versioning is hella confusing). `_MSC_VER = 1700` [corresponds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Visual_C%2B%2B#Internal_version_numbering) to the positively ancient Visual Studio 2012, and that is indeed when MSVC [gained](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/compiler_support/11) `<atomic>` support. 

The potentially confusing part is that the most current version ("Visual Studio 2022 Version 17.x") also has the "17" in there, so maybe a comment might help?

For reference, even VS 2017 (another "17", yay!) is already EOL, so as soon as Python 2.7 is dropped (and thus VS2008), this could be made unconditional. Surely Cython will want to have conservative lower bounds for compiler versions, but older than VS2017 (or maybe even VS2019) makes no sense IMO.

In case it's of interest, this is the [page](https://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/toolchain.html) where scipy documents the relevant constraints for itself (that I help maintain) - as of 1.9, it requires VS2019 (with the vc142 toolchain).

Also perhaps of note. VS 2022 (i.e `_MSC_VER >= 1930`) already [supports](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/overview/visual-cpp-language-conformance?view=msvc-170#note_T) `<stdatomic.h>`, though currently only under `/std:c++latest`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,8 +26,58 @@ typedef struct {
 #endif
 
 #define __pyx_atomic_int_type int
+#define __pyx_nonatomic_int_type int
+
+// for standard C/C++ atomics, get the headers first so we have ATOMIC_INT_LOCK_FREE
+// defined when we decide to use them
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        !defined(__STDC_NO_ATOMICS__))
+    #include <stdatomic.h>
+#elif CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__cplusplus) && ( \
+                    (__cplusplus >= 201103L) || \
+                    (defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER >= 1700)))

@@ -26,8 +26,58 @@ typedef struct {
 #endif
 
 #define __pyx_atomic_int_type int
+#define __pyx_nonatomic_int_type int
+
+// for standard C/C++ atomics, get the headers first so we have ATOMIC_INT_LOCK_FREE
+// defined when we decide to use them
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        !defined(__STDC_NO_ATOMICS__))
+    #include <stdatomic.h>
+#elif CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__cplusplus) && ( \
+                    (__cplusplus >= 201103L) || \
+                    (defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER >= 1700)))
+    #include <atomic>
+#endif
 
-#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (__GNUC__ >= 5 || (__GNUC__ == 4 && \
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \

+// defined when we decide to use them
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \

comment_data.body:
I've added a comment.

I'm inclined not to get into using `<stdatomic.h>` in C++ mode. Everything I've seen suggests that it's very compiler-specific and inconsistent. And I'm trying to get away from compiler-specific and inconsistent as much as possible here
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,8 +26,58 @@ typedef struct {
 #endif
 
 #define __pyx_atomic_int_type int
+#define __pyx_nonatomic_int_type int
+
+// for standard C/C++ atomics, get the headers first so we have ATOMIC_INT_LOCK_FREE
+// defined when we decide to use them
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        !defined(__STDC_NO_ATOMICS__))
+    #include <stdatomic.h>
+#elif CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__cplusplus) && ( \
+                    (__cplusplus >= 201103L) || \
+                    (defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER >= 1700)))

comment_data.body:
> For reference, even VS 2017 (another "17", yay!) is already EOL, so as soon as Python 2.7 is dropped (and thus VS2008), this could be made unconditional. Surely Cython will want to have conservative lower bounds for compiler versions, but older than VS2017 (or maybe even VS2019) makes no sense IMO.

Possibly. There is a non-atomic fallback of course (and it looks like it's been used for years on Windows) so in this case Cython could support any users choosing to use really odd/old compilers with the fallback.

> In case it's of interest, this is the [page](https://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/toolchain.html) where scipy documents the relevant constraints for itself (that I help maintain) - as of 1.9, it requires VS2019 (with the vc142 toolchain).

That was useful. The slight difference is that the majority of Scipy users probably download pre-compiled versions while compiling your own code is the core feature of Cython. So it needs to be a little more tolerant.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,8 +26,58 @@ typedef struct {
 #endif
 
 #define __pyx_atomic_int_type int
+#define __pyx_nonatomic_int_type int
+
+// for standard C/C++ atomics, get the headers first so we have ATOMIC_INT_LOCK_FREE
+// defined when we decide to use them
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        (__STDC_VERSION__ >= __STDC_VERSION__) && \
+                        !defined(__STDC_NO_ATOMICS__))
+    #include <stdatomic.h>
+#elif CYTHON_ATOMICS && (defined(__cplusplus) && ( \
+                    (__cplusplus >= 201103L) || \
+                    (defined(_MSC_VER) && _MSC_VER >= 1700)))

commit.message:
Use standard C or C++ atomics for memoryviews

Use them in preference to the existing compiler-specific
atomic types.

In both cases this requires the 2011 edition of the standard.

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4923
Use MSVC more widely on master

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Use standard C or C++ atomics for memoryviews
